header.title: I am a Sexist?! | Sexism in Art
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: As an erotic artist I hear sometimes that it is sexist what I do. In this video I share with you what makes good & female friendly erotic art in my opinion and how to avoid creating sexist content where women's bodies are objectified. KINKY KARROT WEBSITE: http://www.kinkykarrot.com. PLEASE SHARE THIS VIDEO: https://youtu.be/uaeB7jocovY. FOLLOW ME HERE: Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/kinkykarrot. Instagram: http://www.instagram.com/kinkykarrot. Pinterest: http://www.pinterest.com/kinkykarrot. MUSIC LICENSE. Envato Market Item. Licensor's Author Username: Trendsound. Licensee: Marie Sann. commentThread.commentText: Bravo, Ms. Karrot. A definition for perspective concerning an oft time appropriated term, men have not allowed for the space required for women to define ART...anew. Art is highly subjective but it is a worthwhile endeavor. I can appreciate your coming to terms with the nature of erotic art and it seems you are providing a positive perspective that must be recognized. Hats off to you!

Just because something appeals to a particular demographic it doesn't automatically make it "sexist." Sexism is exclusionary by definition. Not catering to someone in particular isn't excluding, it is simply not catering. There is a very important difference here. If I were to create something I enjoyed specifically for me to enjoy, does that make me sexist/racist/homophobic/transphobic/whatever-ism-ic because I didn't go out of my way to please people that aren't me? No, of course it doesn't. If I make a ham sandwich because I like ham sandwiches, it doesn't make me anti chicken sandwich. I wasn't thumbing my nose at people who prefer chicken sandwiches. It wasn't a secret dig at vegans. It's just a man making a ham sandwich because he likes ham sandwiches. If you're going to make negative assumptions about me and my motives simply because I didn't personally consult you before making a decision, then it is you who is in the wrong, not me. So some people enjoy idealised depictions of the human body. Who cares? What harm does it do? And what's wrong with an idealised body anyway? Shouldn't it be something to aspire to, or at very least admire? If you don't personally like idealised depictions of the human body then that's great. You're entitled to your opinion. However, that doesn't give you the right to go around insulting and attacking people who do like them.
If you do not depict men as sexual objects as well, you are a sell out and a sexist as well. Gee, do naked women paintings sell?
u r such a pervert
theu're no many women in erotic art. and your approach is alway funny details, maybe a woman touch, but so different from classic erotics stuff. And how you play with stereotype is interesting.

replies.commentText: Thank you for your feedback Florin. I know what you mean. And I get the point. But then the question comes up WHAT can be titled as art... and then it gets reaaally complicated. 😅😙

commentThread.commentText:
I'm a pinup artist too... and I can honestly say your artwork elevates your subject to a place of reverence... which is the opposite of sexist. That being said, I do similar artwork... and have been called everything from a masterful genius to a perverted sexist deviant. So, I guess, opinions are really a mixed bag.

I've always believed that 'good' or 'successful' art elicits an emotional response; either good or bad. One of my favourite things to do is listen to what people say about my artwork, without them knowing I'm the artist,  when they're being shown in galleries. And while I love the ones that love my work, the critics that downright hate my work are a lot more interesting. I can honestly say that I didn't put anything disgusting, sexist, or terrible in my artwork, so when people see those things in there, it makes me wonder if they brought that to the experience themselves.

replies.commentText: Hey Bryan! Thank you for your feedback. Very interesting to get an opinion from another (pin-up) artist. I love by the way that you are listening silently to the opinions of the viewer of your art. That's a very brave thing to do cause I can imagine it can be hurting sometimes as well as people can be mean. 😅 but I understand that the artist can learn a lot by it. About how the his art is seen. And as you said also about preconceived opinions about erotic art in general. I will try out this "undercover" thing as well if I have the chance... 😁😉

commentThread.commentText: I definitely don't think Kinky Karrot's art is sexist, but I also think that some of the criteria used to determine whether something is sexist is fuzzy. For example, I don't think there's necessarily anything wrong with an artist only being interested in drawing sexualized women who don't have any real depth of character. What matters most are the ideas behind it; if an artist draws sexualized women as an expression of his/her ideas that women are MERELY sexual beings, or aren't worthy of respect, or are only useful to a sexual capacity, then yeah, I would characterize the artist as sexist, but I don't know how that would be expressed in their art, since the art itself could be identical to that by another artist who has liberal, progressive, feminist views on women. It's a bit of a case of "judging a book by its cover". But I definitely wouldn't characterize Karrot's art as sexist, because (as she explains in the video), a lot of the features of her art show a deeper, richer view on women than would otherwise be shown by most artists who may ACTUALLY be sexist.

I think sexism in art is when the artist fails to depict a character as a person with agency and instead creates a soulless object for their or other's pleasure. It's more than just idealized feminine features. Many sexist artists fail to depict their characters, especially females, as unique individuals. They see a collection of body parts before they picture a person in their mind. Many of their characters have the same facial features, poses, and bodies. Many of their characters aren't expressive or enthusiastic. I think it's important for us as artists to try to replicate reality, especially in fantasy, so that the immersion is stronger and the people we depict are respected.

commentThread.commentText: I don't think what you do is. I think it all just comes down to a matter of preference. Each person has their own limits and no matter how you try to do it someone will always be offended for some reason. If I may I will use me as an example. I just completed a pinup piece with a young lady in jeans and a shirt leaning up against her 68 Camaro. When I posted this I also stated I wanted to do more pinup work. While most of the responses where great I did get a few of I shouldn't be objectifying women. I was a little confused on what I created was bad?? I come to realize I don't care. I'll do what I like and those that like it will support me and those that don't no longer have any affect on what I create.

commentThread.commentText: Very very important discussion and i think it needs much more space and time to discuss. I absolutely love your work and adore a lot of other art when it comes to womens body, erotic and nudity. It does not mean i am a lesbian or sexist. I enjoy and celebrate the body of a woman... in every shape. I see art and another point of view. In my opionion it has to do a lot with the costumers/viewers personal view about life. When is see art, a human being, curves, sensuality ... others may se e sexism. Too many people feel offended by everthing today that they don't know or understand. Years ago i was a Burlesque Performer. From my point of view: I was a performer, an artist, an actress, it was a show, an illusion. I was celebrating being a woman. I was playful, charming, entertaining and made people smile (and sometimes blush). But some men were thinking "i am a slut, easy to get, have no brain, just need attention". So who is the sexist? Lots of Love from Berlin.

commentThread.commentText: Sexualizing a body isn't sexism, at least in the context of your art, since it depicts these characters as sexual beings, but it doesn't say that women ar e sexual beings, it says that this characters in particular were created and design to be sexy

replies.commentText: Thanx! :* Glad you see it like this.

commentThread.commentText: The short answer is not in my opinion. You are creating characters that are consenting and reveling in their own sexuality and sexual power. Hardly a basis for any definition of sexism. The longer answer. If we take the definition o f sexism for the Oxford English dictionary as "prejudice, stereotyping, or discrimination on the basis of sex" I don't find your characters prejudical, none are saying they are of less (or greater) worth than others simply because if th ere gender. Are you discriminating by drawing the female form? If it is a form you like and have a desire to draw, then know. Was Van Gogh discriminating against roses because he liked to draw sunflowers? I doubt many would say so. So are you stereotyping? I think there is enough variety within your work to make the argument this is not the case. I suppose one could make the case that your "Superhoeroines" ("Harlequin", "Amazon Goddess" & "Lois & Superman") are more stereotypical images. However, that argument would be based on the long narrative history of those characters and not t heir gender. Was the work of Archie Dickens sexist? I don't believe so. His characters always had a playful/impish quality that showed their ownership of their sexuality. Was the work of Irving Klaw sexist. A topic of great debate, given some of the most famous Bettie Page bondage photos where done by Klaw. On the surface and looking at a particular photo, I have had people tell me that it is. "How is a woman in bondage and peril not sexist!" But, must not one look at a body of work to make a claim. Show that same person the female dominatrix photos he took, and they often change their tune on those photos. Add to that the myriad of specific costume and shoe fetish photos he did. Which are sexist and which aren't. Is is body of work sexist? When looking at it as a totality, I would have to say no. If anything, relative to its time, it was the antithe sis of sexism. Are the main characters in the Story of O by Pauline Réage and the Beauty series by Ann Rice sexist, even though we have female authors writing about main characters often in the position of being female sexual submissives? Since in both cases, the characters are choosing to do what they do ONLY because they OWN their sexuality. People/characters who truly own their own sexuality are still far from the norm (at least here in the US, perhaps Berlin in is different, although I doubt it) People/characters who truly own their own sexuality are those who truly understand their own power and freedom. When understanding one's own power and freedom becomes the norm, perhaps than it can be stereotyped. (Although I have my doubts, sadly, that day will ever come.) Your works don't meet any of the criteria for being sexist. Please keep doing what you love. You are so very talented and your subject matter is worthy of the fine creations you bring to life.

replies.commentText:
Thank you Rob, for this detailed comment!
I am glad that you see it like this.
In general it is really a tough topic. It was really important to me to bring it up at one point but I can just scratch it here. So even more I am thankful for such extensive comments like yours. I appreciate that you took the time.  :*
And what you said about people who own their own sexuality - I am also very convinced that they are the happier and healthier ones. But for most of all coming out in this society means to be very brave. I hope to be able to change that at least a tiny little bit with my project. At least by opening peoples eyes, encouraging them to be more open and also true to themselves.

commentThread.commentText: Hi Marie, ich schreibe einfachheitshalber mal auf Deutsch... :-) Sexismus in der Kunst... hmmmm. Kein einfaches Thema, denn natürlich könnte man wieder mit dem Argument der Kunstfreiheit kommen, die ja auch ein Grundrecht ist. Ebenso könnte man sagen "das liegt im Auge des Betrachters". Das wäre mir persönlich aber zu einfach. Natürlich "darf" Kunst sexistisch sein, wenn man danach geht. Kunst "darf" auch provozieren oder politisch sein... Dass dies allerdings schon öfter nach hinten losging, ist nichts neues und ich weiß nicht, wo man da die imaginäre Linie ziehen sollte. Sexismus in der Kunst würde für mich persönlich da anfangen, wo dargestellter Sex nur plakativ ist und bewusst provokant eingesetzt wird. Wenn Darstellungen herabwürdigend sind und es nur Mittel zum Zweck ist, ist eine unschöne Grenze erreicht, die mit der Absicht überschritten wird, um anzuecken und zu provozieren. Ist es dann noch Kunst oder ist es dann Pornographie? Wie gesagt, ein schwieriges Thema... Anders verhält es sich mit erotischer Kunst, die in meinen Augen in ihrer Darstellung auch viel ansprechender sein kann. Es kann ein Blick, eine Geste sein, die das Knistern in einem Bild vermittelt. Das Spiel von Licht- und Schattenwurf auf den dargestellten Charakteren. Zeichnerische Andeutungen, die das nicht sichtbare erahnen lassen, können viel ansprechender und inspirierender sein, als das Offensichtliche. ;-) Herzliche Grüße -Marcel

replies.commentText:
Ja Marcel
Es fällt mir selbst schwer, über so ein komplexes Thema auf Englisch zu sprechen. Kann dich also gut verstehen... 
Wenn Kunst sexistisch ist, um zu provozieren und eine (gute) Message zu verbreiten, sehe ich es vollkommen ein. Es darf nur nicht sein, wenn es positiv dargestellt und verherrlicht wird. 
Ich finde auch, dass Pornografie gut sein kann. Ich denke, nicht alle Arten von Pornografie müssen sexistisch sein. Im Gegenteil. In dem Comic, den ich für Kinky Karrot machen werde, werde ich pornografische Elemente nutzen, die nichts mit Sexismus zu tun haben! Es geht also auf jeden Fall!
Das größte Problem ist meiner Meinung einfach das schlimme Frauenbild, das bei vielen leider nach wie vor in den Köpfen steckt. Frauen werden viel zu oft zu sehr auf ihre sexuellen Attribute reduziert und zu Sexobjekten runtergestuft. Das müssen wir ändern!

Kinky Karrot 
Genau das meinte ich, Marie. Provokant im positiven Sinne, um die leider immer noch verschrobene Denkweise vieler Hinterwäldler offen zu legen und diesen damit bewusst vor den Kopf zu stoßen, halte ich für mehr als berechtigt. Starke Frauen, zu denen ich Dich natürlich auch zähle, die offen mit Sexualität umgehen und einem Teil der Gesellschaft lächelnd den Spiegel vorhalten, um zu zeigen, dass sie mit ihrem Schubladen-Denken mit Vollgas vor die Wand fahren. Wer Deine offene Art und künstlerisch ästhetische Darstellung sexistisch findet, der haut auch zum Feuermachen noch zwei Steine aneinander.
Natürlich kann auch Pornografie positiv sein. Mir ging es dort hauptsächlich um den Punkt der Herabwürdigung. Da ist die Grenze deutlich überschritten und wir wären wieder beim Thema Hinterwäldler. Aktuelle Meldungen aus Hollywood und auch Deutschland zeigen, dass von dieser Spezies leider noch sehr viele Exemplare existieren.
Auf Deinen Kinky Karrot-Comic freue ich mich schon sehr!
